snippet: The kiltie flap, an oddball golf-shoe detail and once an inescapable facet of 1950s country clubs, makes a surprising return.
abstract: Kiltie flap, fringed tongue of leather originally found in men's golf shoes from the 1950s, has become a popular trend in men's loafers today. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IN some fashion quarters, enthusiasm for old-school heritage style is fading like embers. But elsewhere, it is raging out of control, with evermore vivid hues and ornate detail. One need only glance down, at the recent spate of colorized bucks and saddle shoes. Or take a gander at the even more surprising reappearance of an over-the-vamp, over-the-top shoe detail one might have thought was gone forever: the kiltie. Like some soap-opera character declared dead in a South American plane crash, only to be found alive years later (and looking suspiciously like a completely different actor), the charmingly oddball golf-shoe detail that is the kiltie is back, in a totally different incarnation. Once an inescapable facet of 1950s country clubs, a kiltie is a long fringed tongue of leather that attaches to a golf shoe's inside tongue and folds over the laces.
